This is the NSTA site:
 
 http://www.nsta.org/sciencenews
 
 
 I find it very interesting. I hope you do, too.
Carl Sagan called science the "candle in the dark." We need to get away from this obsession with religion and return to science.

How does a so called "return to science" happen? What are we returning to? 
 Science and religion are both important topics. Religion and philosophy may seem useless to many, but science cannot give us answers to moral dilemmas. Science cannot tell us why we should live, how we ought to live, etc. 
 I guess that's all sort of obvious, though.

Carl Sagan called science the "candle in the dark." We need to get away from this obsession with religion and return to science.

 
 It doesn't need to be an either/or scenario to begin with. Religion and science have co-existed for the most part peacefully for the last several hundred years. Some of the more influential scientists in history were devoutly religious. The myth that they can't both exist simultaneously is an unfortunate misconception on the part of both some religious people and some science-related people and is mostly a pretty new way of thinking (relatively speaking anyway). The key is understanding the roles and limits of each.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  A source of science links....
